title: 113_hr4831
content: The Act titled "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014" allows for federal matching payments for state new manufacturing jobs training tax credits. The Act "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014" authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to make quarterly payments to eligible community colleges based on new manufacturing job withholding matches for trainees. Eligible community colleges are defined as public higher education institutions. Eligible community colleges are public higher education institutions that award mostly 2-year associate's degrees acceptable for credit towards a bachelor's degree. They must be located in a state with a new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program and participate in the program by meeting specific requirements. The State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program is established by a state government. State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for qualified training, where State income taxes withheld by the employer for the trainee will be remitted to the college instead of the State. The new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for qualified training. State income taxes withheld by the employer for the trainee will be remitted to the college instead of the State, serving as payment for education provided by the college. This arrangement also affects the State income tax liability of the trainee. The program allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for qualified training. The contract involves the college providing training directly to individuals designated by the employer or through a qualified training provider. The eligible community college will provide qualified training to individuals designated by the employer or through a training provider, without charging tuition or fees. The employer must hire these individuals for full-time employment at a job site within the State, paying them a wage of at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage. The employer must pay individuals a wage of at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage or the amount specified by the State program. The employer will remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of the individual to the community college for training costs specified in the contract. The employer must pay individuals a wage of at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage or the amount specified by the State program. The contract for qualified training must specify the entire cost, including equipment and materials, and be reasonable by market standards. Qualified training refers to education or skills necessary for the job or employment. The individual must receive education or skills necessary for the job, obtain required licenses or credentials, aligned with industry standards, for a new job. The State program for new manufacturing jobs training tax credit requires eligible trainees to be hired for new jobs aligned with industry standards. The tax credit program requires eligible trainees to be hired for new jobs that result in a net increase in employment for the employer, not recalling workers or filling existing positions. The tax credit program requires eligible trainees to be hired for new jobs that result in a net increase in employment for the employer, not recalling workers or filling existing positions. Only U.S. employees at job sites in the United States are considered for the program, and aggregation rules apply for related employers. Cooperation with local workforce investment boards is also required. For the State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program, employers and eligible community colleges can collaborate with local workforce investment boards to hire and train individuals. An eligible trainee is someone who received qualified training through an eligible community college under the program. An "eligible trainee" is an individual who received qualified training through an eligible community college under a State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program and is employed full-time by the employer who was part of the training contract. The trainee must work at a job site in the same state as the community college, earn a wage that meets specific requirements, work in a new job, and require the qualified training for their job. In subsection (d)(2)(iii), an eligible trainee must work in a job that meets the new job requirement of subsection (d)(4) and in a job where qualified training is required. An eligible manufacturing employer is defined as a person who employs individuals in manufacturing, with facilities in the US, and primary business classified in sectors 31, 32, or 33 of the NAICS. (g) Appropriation.--Sums in the Treasury are appropriated as necessary to carry out this section. (h) Remission of State Income Tax Withholdings Not Treated as Payments for Training or Education.--For eligible manufacturing employers, remitted State income tax to a community college is not considered a payment by the employer for tax credits or deductions, but as payment of income taxes owed by the employee. The employer's payments for tax credits or deductions under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are treated as income tax payments by the employee. For eligible trainees, withheld State income tax remitted to a community college or payments made under subsection (a) are not considered income. These amounts are treated as payments for State income taxes for deduction purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
